awd_titl_txt: Conference: 2023 Chemistry Education Research and Practice Gordon Research Conference and Gordon Research Seminar
awd_abstract_narration:
This project seeks to serve the national interest by advancing and propagating knowledge of chemistry teaching and learning as well as the application of this knowledge in undergraduate chemistry learning environments. The Summer 2023 Gordon Research Conference (GRC) and Gordon Research Seminar (GRS) on Chemistry Education Research and Practice (CERP) will feature cutting-edge chemistry education research. They will bring researchers and chemistry teaching scholars together to discuss recent methods and findings as well as applications of the research in instructional practice. The 2023 CERP GRC builds on a successful tradition of GRCs while it innovates in the areas of diversity, equity, inclusion, and belonging. COVID-19 and recent social movements have prompted an increased amount of scholarship on equity, social justice, and inclusion in chemistry teaching and learning. The conference organizers will leverage this new scholarship, recruit speakers and conferees from groups and institutions that have been traditionally underrepresented in the chemical sciences, and highlight a programmatic focus on diversity, equity, inclusion, and belonging. 2023 also marks the first year of a CERP GRS convening, which will provide unique professional development opportunities for new and early scholars who conduct chemistry education research. These scholars are not only the next generation of chemistry education researchers, but they are also among the next generation of college and university faculty. By participating in the GRS and GRC, they will build the necessary professional and communal networks to support research-based reforms in chemistry teaching and learning. For the field of chemistry education, the combined 2023 GRC and GRS on CERP will advance access, quality, and reform in undergraduate chemistry teaching and learning.

The Summer 2023 Gordon Research Conference and Seminar on Chemistry Education Research and Practice (CERP) will: (1) stimulate more and better chemistry education research and scholarly teaching in chemistry with increased coordination among research programs and the intentional implementation of evidence-based teaching innovations; (2) build a more diversified group of scholars carrying out chemistry education research and scholarly teaching in chemistry; and (3) broaden early scholars’ expertise in framing research questions, employing diverse research methods, and applying theoretical orientations by deliberately organizing sessions on the alignment among these core research skills. These three goals will be attained through a carefully designed program and diverse and highly qualified speaker and discussion leader selection complemented by the intimate conference environment afforded by a GRC and a GRS. Specifically, the GRS provides a special opportunity for graduate students and postdoctoral fellows to form professional networks, receive feedback on their work, and engage with leaders in the field from outside of their own research groups. The GRC program includes transformative concepts, particularly in the areas of diversity, equity, inclusion, and belonging as well as scholarly responses to the COVID-19 pandemic’s effect on chemistry education research and practice. The structure and content of the Gordon Research Seminar and Conference on Chemistry Education Research and Practice are carefully conceived and organized to achieve its three goals. More broadly, the diverse group of speakers and discussion leaders, the inaugural CERP GRS, and the GRC Power Hour will contribute to all conferees’ development and build awareness to support those who have been historically excluded in science. Additionally, the concurrent programming and networking segments will further conversations about unconscious bias, mentoring and sponsorship, and strategies for addressing harassment and inappropriate behavior. Such discussions and interactions will help seed the culture change needed to support the professional growth of all chemists. The NSF IUSE: EDU Program supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students. Through the Engaged Student Learning track, the program supports the creation, exploration, and implementation of promising practices and tools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award provided financial resources to support the recruitment of a diverse group of program contributors and conference participants for the 2023 Gordon Research Conference on Chemistry Education Research and Practice (GRC-CERP) and the inaugural Gordon Research Seminar on Chemistry Education Research and Practice (GRS-CERP). 

The GRC-CERP theme was Coordinating the Production and Consumption of Knowledge on Chemistry Teaching and Learning, and it was held at Bates College in Lewiston, Maine on July 9-14, 2023. The GRC-CERP welcomed 180 attendees (66% female, 62% male, 2% non-binary) from the U.S. (87%) and across the world. Attendees included graduate students (32%), postdoctoral researchers (11%), faculty (53%), administrators (2%), and other scientific professionals (2%) from a broad array of colleges and universities. The 22 speakers and 141 poster presenters engaged attendees in topics from chemistry education research and practice at the frontiers of the discipline. Scientific conversations launched in the discussion segments of the program continued throughout the conference at poster sessions, meals, and social events providing ample opportunities for collaboration and innovation. 

Participants completed a GRC evaluation in which 87% of attendees rated the GRC-CERP above average in all of the evaluation areas (science, discussion, management, atmosphere and suitability). For comparison, the average performance rating for all conferences in 2023 was 79%, placing the GRC-CERP in the “High-Performing Group,” as designated by the Gordon Research Conferences. Furthermore, the session attendance rates for the GRC-CERP were 10%-20% higher than the 2023 all-conference session averages. 

NSF funding supported the participation of 71 GRC-CERP attendees, including speakers, discussion leaders, poster presenters, and junior members of this scholarly community. This diverse and rich collection of researchers and teacher scholars featured cutting-edge chemistry education. Bringing educational researchers and chemistry teaching scholars together, along with scholars from allied scientific fields, advanced the community’s understanding of the current challenges, issues, evidenced solutions, and promising strategies in chemistry teaching and learning. 

The GRS-CERP theme was Discussing the Epistemological Interplay of Research Contexts, Questions, & Methodologies Across Formal and Informal Chemistry Teaching and Learning Contexts, and immediately prior to the GRC on July 8-9, 2023. The GRS-CERP welcomed 73 attendees (25% male, 69% female, 5% non-binary, 1% did not report) from the US (89%) and abroad. All but 2 of these attendees stayed for the GRC afterwards. 67% of attendees were graduate students, 23% were post doctoral researchers, and 10% were early career faculty or faculty mentors. The 14 speakers and discussants and 67 poster presenters, all of whom were graduate or postdoctoral trainees, engaged attendees in a range of cutting edge topics geared toward tangible takeaways for improving teaching and learning. These scientific discussions carried on beyond the sessions and throughout the rest of the GRC week.

Participants completed an evaluation survey, where they were asked to rank the highest strengths and areas of improvement for the GRS. Among the top strengths attendees identified were that the speaker pool and poster sessions were diverse, interactive, and engaging (51%), the environment was respective and collegial (36%), the conference attendance was diverse (22%), and the scientific content was cutting edge (18%). For areas for improvement, the majority of attendees selected none of the above (63%), supporting the overall strength and impact of the CERP GRS.

NSF funding supported the participation of 67 attendees (92%), including speakers, poster presenters, and discussants; along with additional funding sources, we were able to offset costs for registration and/or travel costs for 100% of attendees. This unique opportunity to highlight the work of graduate and postdoctoral researchers from a wide range of topic areas showcased the up-and-coming areas of growth within chemistry education research. This unique opportunity built deep community, facilitated scholarly exchange, and contributed to the professional development and growth of the field’s new generation of scholars and leaders.
